#Summary1=(human1) This textbook excerpt goes over the history of the concept of atoms in chemistry, including Ancient Greek views and Dalton's Atomic Theory, which stipulates that all matter is made of atoms, which are the smallest units of matter and belong to distinct element types, which are neither created nor destroyed in the course of chemical reactions.

#Summary2=(human2) This textbook section opens with a discussion of atomic theories from ancient Greece before presenting John Dalton's five postulates regarding atomic theory, as published in 1807, along with a few examples of fictional chemical reactions for the purpose of checking understanding.

#Summary3=(human3) This text summarizes two early views about the structure of matter—one that it was composed of small particles, called atomos, and another that it consisted of combinations of fire, earth, air, and water—and lists the five postulates of English schoolteacher John Dalton’s hypothesis, published in 1807, that the behavior of matter could be explained with an atomic theory.
#Summary4=(human4) This section of a textbook describes an overview of Dalton's Atomic Theory as it relates to matter and its proposed proportions.

#Summary5=(human5) This section of a textbook describes postulates of John Dalton’s 1807 atomic theory: matter is composed of atoms, each element consists of only one type of atom, atoms of one element are different from atoms of all other elements, compounds are made of atoms of two or more elements in whole number ratios, and atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change.
#Text=2.1 Early Ideas in Atomic Theory
#Text=By the end of this section , you will be able to :
#Text=State the postulates of Dalton ’s atomic theory
#Text=Use postulates of Dalton ’s atomic theory to explain the laws of definite and multiple proportions
#Text=The earliest recorded discussion of the basic structure of matter comes from ancient Greek philosophers , the scientists of their day .

#Text=In the fifth century BC , Leucippus and Democritus argued that all matter was composed of small , finite particles that they called atomos , a term derived from the Greek word for “ indivisible . ”
#Text=They thought of atoms as moving particles that differed in shape and size , and which could join together .
#Text=Later , Aristotle and others came to the conclusion that matter consisted of various combinations of the four “ elements ” — fire , earth , air , and water — and could be infinitely divided .
#Text=Interestingly , these philosophers thought about atoms and “ elements ” as philosophical concepts , but apparently never considered performing experiments to test their ideas .

#Text=The Aristotelian view of the composition of matter held sway for over two thousand years , until English schoolteacher John Dalton helped to revolutionize chemistry with his hypothesis that the behavior of matter could be explained using an atomic theory .
#Text=First published in 1807 , many of Dalton ’s hypotheses about the microscopic features of matter are still valid in modern atomic theory .
#Text=Here are the postulates of Dalton ’s atomic theory .
#Text=1. Matter is composed of exceedingly small particles called atoms .
#Text=An atom is the smallest unit of an element that can participate in a chemical change .
#Text=2. An element consists of only one type of atom , which has a mass that is characteristic of the element and is the same for all atoms of that element ( Figure 2.2 ) .
#Text=A macroscopic sample of an element contains an incredibly large number of atoms , all of which have identical chemical properties .
#Text=Figure 2.2

#Text=A pre-1982 copper penny ( left ) contains approximately 3 ×× 10 22 copper atoms ( several dozen are represented as brown spheres at the right ) , each of which has the same chemical properties .
#Text=( credit : modification of work by “ slgckgc ” / Flickr )
#Text=3. Atoms of one element differ in properties from atoms of all other elements .
#Text=4. A compound consists of atoms of two or more elements combined in a small , whole - number ratio .
#Text=In a given compound , the numbers of atoms of each of its elements are always present in the same ratio ( Figure 2.3 ) .
#Text=Figure 2.3
#Text=Copper(II) oxide , a powdery , black compound , results from the combination of two types of atoms — copper ( brown spheres ) and oxygen ( red spheres ) — in a 1 : 1 ratio .
#Text=( credit : modification of work by “ Chemicalinterest ” / Wikimedia Commons )
#Text=5. Atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change , but are instead rearranged to yield substances that are different from those present before the change ( Figure 2.4 ) .
#Text=Figure 2.4

#Text=When the elements copper ( a shiny , red - brown solid , shown here as brown spheres ) and oxygen ( a clear and colorless gas , shown here as red spheres ) react , their atoms rearrange to form a compound containing copper and oxygen ( a powdery , black solid ) .
#Text=( credit copper : modification of work by http://images-of-elements.com/copper.php )
#Text=Dalton ’s atomic theory provides a microscopic explanation of the many macroscopic properties of matter that you ’ve learned about .

#Text=For example , if an element such as copper consists of only one kind of atom , then it can not be broken down into simpler substances , that is , into substances composed of fewer types of atoms .

#Text=And if atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change , then the total mass of matter present when matter changes from one type to another will remain constant ( the law of conservation of matter ) .
#Text=EXAMPLE 2.1
#Text=Testing Dalton ’s Atomic Theory
#Text=In the following drawing , the green spheres represent atoms of a certain element .
#Text=The purple spheres represent atoms of another element .
#Text=If the spheres touch , they are part of a single unit of a compound .
#Text=Does the following chemical change represented by these symbols violate any of the ideas of Dalton ’s atomic theory ?
#Text=If so , which one ?
#Text=Solution
#Text=The starting materials consist of two green spheres and two purple spheres .
#Text=The products consist of only one green sphere and one purple sphere .
#Text=This violates Dalton ’s postulate that atoms are neither created nor destroyed during a chemical change , but are merely redistributed .
#Text=( In this case , atoms appear to have been destroyed . )
#Text=Check Your Learning
#Text=In the following drawing , the green spheres represent atoms of a certain element .
#Text=The purple spheres represent atoms of another element .
#Text=If the spheres touch , they are part of a single unit of a compound .
#Text=Does the following chemical change represented by these symbols violate any of the ideas of Dalton ’s atomic theory ?
#Text=If so , which one ?
#Text=ANSWER :
#Text=The starting materials consist of four green spheres and two purple spheres .
#Text=The products consist of four green spheres and two purple spheres .
#Text=This does not violate any of Dalton ’s postulates :
#Text=Atoms are neither created nor destroyed , but are redistributed in small , whole - number ratios .
